Men of our order, seeking out savages for God and the Catholic King, examined the coverts of its forests, the summits of its mountains, and the banks of its remotest riverS‚ traversing, to the utmost of their ability, every part of the pro- vince, always risking, and osten losing, their lives. In Peru and Mexico, there is no corner which the Europeans, attracted by the hope of gold, have not searched int03 but we are still unacquainted with great part of Paraguay, a region unproductive of gold, and, therefore, wanting the requisite allurement. As for what is discovered, who can deny that it is almost entirely owing to the efforts of the Mis- sionaries? The plains which they traversed, the rivers which they crossed‚ together with the distances of placeS, they have noted with the utmost fidelity‚ though not always with equal art.

Paraguay is subject to the King of Spain, in whose authority it is ruled by three gover- nours, and as many bishops. Each province has its governour3 the first is that of La Plata, on the banks of which is the city of Buenos-Ayres‚ the seat of the royal governour, and of a bishop.
